üí¨I can't understand why Electronic Arts, when reviewing player reviews and opinions, is going all out, serving us another NfS‚Ñ¢ installment in the series with the same atmosphere that turned so many people off after Payback. I don't expect to ever play NfS‚Ñ¢: Underground 3, but I'd like to see at least its spiritual successor. On the other hand, this doesn't mean that NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat should be written off right away, because after all, Ghost Games not only eliminated microtransactions and randomized Speed Cards, the biggest problem we had playing NfS‚Ñ¢ Payback, but also added an interesting element that could make Heat a truly great game.

üéÆNfS‚Ñ¢ Heat does remind one of the incredible Dying Light to some extent, as the new chapter of the legendary racing game series provides a day and night cycle. However, the nightfall is not a condition, as the time of day in the game can be adjusted through the menu. Daytime is when we are engaged in legal races to make money which is then spent on car parts and performance adaptations of the car. But this is not like in NfS‚Ñ¢ Payback as in Heat the player decides what parts of his/her car to improve. Similar to the previous one, before racing, the car's required level to participate has to be checked and compared with that of the player's vehicle. NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat, however, is hardly a grinding game. This doesn't change the fact that to unlock individual story missions and side quests, we must first complete a series of different races.

Participating in the various competitions held after dark doesn't reward us financially, but rather rewards us with special reputation points that allows us to advance to new experience levels (to gain them faster, it's worth teasing the cops and increasing your Heat level, which is the equivalent of police stars in GTA). The new story missions become available and at the same time it's possible to get new cars and tuning parts. Still, it doesn't come easy as the police will be after you (law enforcement officers also do their rounds in the city during the day but do not interfere). It is not surprising, anyway, as we are selling illegal night races, and a special squad has been created to tackle crime. Therefore, just like in the aforementioned Dying Light, we have to be constantly on our guard. While on easy difficulty, the cops practically crash into other cars, on medium, not to mention hard, they can be incredibly persistent. We can eliminate them in various ways, by repeatedly crashing into police cars or using gadgets acquired during the campaign.

NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat doesn't return to the winter atmosphere of 2015's NfS‚Ñ¢, but we still encounter heavily exaggerated characters and a terribly childish story. The action takes place in Palm City (the name obliges, so it's a bit like Miami), and our task, first and foremost is to prove our skills in various competitions (classic races, time trials, drifts...). This is the only way to gain entry into the League, whose members have significantly better cars and parts to modify their performance. All this to ultimately become a master driver... The story is clearly forced, although I must admit that the course of events can be a bit surprising at times. I quickly stopped caring about the characters' fates and focused solely on what NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat is best at: the races.

I've mentioned that NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat also offers side missions in addition to the main missions. However, it's very common for the story related stages to be essentially... I have no clue. Following the reaching of a marker, there occurs a slight interaction regarding nothing, and next, a npc takes you to your goal where a race starts, and needless to say, winning is the only option for you. Once you reach the finish line, a few seconds of cutscene triggers, and that's it... The game's moments of more story focused gameplay are actually few and far between. But maybe that's for the best, since many people believe that story and racing gameplay are a perfect match?

However, when we forget about the story dedicated to who knows who and start exploring the city, we notice that Palm City is a particularly deserted place. Already in 2011's Driver: San Francisco, we encountered a bustling metropolis (and by the way, I hope Ghost Games learns from Ubisoft how to craft an engaging story in a racing game, because in that Driver, the story kept me glued to the screen until the very end), where people strolled on the sidewalks, while a wide variety of cars drove along the streets... I think the only place with less traffic is at the Mataveri International Airport

Mentioning of traffic, it's worth noting that in NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat ironically I had no sense of speed... Even though I saw my car clocked at 186 miles per hour, it actually behaved as if it was trying to stay within the speed limit on the expressway. What more can I say? That's not how it should be, right?.

Each of the nearly 130 cars handles completely differently. Interestingly, despite the arcade style driving model, you can still feel even the slightest change in parts. This is the reason behind the engagement of NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat even with its numerous flaws since it has the notion that it is not simply unlocking new skins of the car but rather unlocking stronger and more powerful cars. Moreover, those people who like tinkering with the hood of a digital car would definitely be happy.

NfS‚Ñ¢ Heat is a multiplayer game but you can still play the campaign alone. Like in DriveClub, you join a crew (here referred to simply as a Crew) that can have up to 32 members. To start with, a crew is randomly assigned to you, but you can freely choose any crew or even create your own. Individual points are awarded to each player, but they are transferred to the team's account, which enables every team member to get many benefits, such as, of course, cash and reputation points being accumulated faster. Moreover, gradually, Crew Time Trials will be also unlocked which are special time trials that let you compete with other players from your crew.

"Not great, not terrible." The meme from the Chernobyl series perfectly describes NFS Heat, which isn't bad overall, but it's not particularly great either. If you have low expectations for this type of game, and simply want to drive and tune your favorite cars, you should find everything you need in NFS Heat.

üß†Heat primarily addresses a few of the weaknesses of the two previous installments and, tentatively took cues from Forza Horizon. So, regular tuning parts have returned instead of lootbox cards, the story is a bit more bearable, and the game world has opened up thanks to the near-complete destruction of environmental elements. The ability to outfit your driver in countless combinations of hipster outfits has also been borrowed from Forza. The biggest draw of this installment, however, is the clear division between day and night racing a mechanic that could be truly fantastic if only it were properly refined.

In NFS Heat, every time you are faced with the decision to leave the city during the day or at night, legal racing during the day is nothing like the excitement of going out at night, as you can probably guess. However, since you need to earn money during the day and build your reputation at night to advance the story and unlock faster and faster cars, you'll likely find yourself wanting to divide your time between both. 

During the day, you basically just admire the surroundings and earn cash for further purchases of upgraded parts and new cars. The race tracks are surrounded by barriers, traffic is limited, and the police don't interfere it's simply a sporting event in the city, although I wouldn't expect it to have the atmosphere of NFS ProStreet.

What happens after dark, however, is a completely different story. Illegal races take place among other road users, lack any sporting flair, and police cars lurk along the route. But that's nothing new in the Need for Speed series... So where is the excitement that I previously mentioned coming from? It's from mechanics similar to those in the new Tom Clancy's The Division.
Racing at night is like entering the "Twilight Zone." The more we break the law and increase the level of police "heat" around us (the titular "heat"), the more reputation we can gain, but it's also easy to lose everything in an instant when we can't get back to the garage. Because in NFS Heat the cops are like a pit bull, when they sniff out a pirate breaking the road code in a tuned Golf, they won't let up, and we'll lose both our time and our points.

If in recent NFS games, the police acted like city guards carrying parking barriers, now they resemble an anti-terrorist squad, swiftly sweeping us off the pavement. Essentially, from a heat level of "3" and above, it's a done deal. You can only escape with some luck or by cheating the system. The police cars act like battering rams in a gymkhana - fast, nimble, hard to destroy, and when one is eliminated another shows up.

Because of these small AI shenanigans, NFS Heat at Night became my first ever stealth car game! With a lot of reputation points to collect, I opted to drive at a snail's pace and stare at the minimap to avoid the red police car icons. I don't mind a greater challenge, but the main issue here was the lack of balance.

NFS Heat also boasts a pretty beautiful environment and game world. It's clear that things are slow, but adapting the Frostbite engine to a racing game is progressing. It's still not as beautiful as Forza Horizon, but Palm City, modeled after Miami, and its rural setting are certainly appealing. The skyscrapers and the incredibly detailed port and gravel pit structures look particularly impressive. Scattered throughout the city are also original graffiti and murals, discovering which provides a welcome stimulus to explore the game's world.

It's a shame, however, that despite all this grandeur and detail, Palm City is a completely dead city. The number of cars on the streets evokes associations with New Year's Eve traffic at 8 a.m. - there are no people on the sidewalks, no trains running, and no signs that anyone lives here. Need for Speed remains relegated to its backwardness, despite games like Midnight Club: Los Angeles, which demonstrated back in 2008 that a metropolis can be vibrant in a racing game. The most active element on the streets of Palm City is the rain, which falls several times a day, as if the developers wanted to boast only about the reflections on the puddles.

For those who enjoy visual tuning, you can not only replace the sills, hood, rims, mirrors, and bumpers in almost thirty categories, but you can also change the exhaust sound and put your own graffiti, which can be found all over the city. You can also customize yourself‚Äîyour character, that is. With almost 700 different hats, hairstyles, sweatshirts and shoes‚Äîmany with the Three Stripes and just one pair with a cat.

Every time I heard about a publisher taking a break from its annual cycle to create a truly excellent Need for Speed, to return to its roots and reboot the series, I envisioned a modern game that would once again set standards in its genre. I dreamed of a game with Hollywood-style street chases, a cockpit view that could be customized for the first time, a bustling city, and a decent driving model. And while competing titles have offered most of these things for years and are experimenting with new features like changing seasons, Need for Speed unfortunately stagnates, serving up the same old story every time.

‚úÖPros.
+ Finally, a beautiful, detailed city and its surroundings
+ Extensive car tuning options
+ Varied missions during the story campaign
+ Environmental destruction allows for a lot of freedom while driving
+ Concept of risking your performance during nighttime escapades...

‚ùåCons.
- Overly aggressive and powerful police
- Little variety in race modes
- A completely dead, almost empty city
- Lack of new features and solutions long-present in the competition

üßæSummary.
It's been a while since i've experienced this kind of stagnation, staying true to our premise, but being stuck in outdated solutions. It's high time for a small revolution. Heat is undoubtedly the best NFS game of the eight generation, but compared to previous installments in the series, it's no mean feat. This is the title with which the series should have launched on the ninth generation of gaming devices. Perhaps today it would be in a completely different, better form? For now, this is the acceptable minimum...neither completely bad nor too good. "Not great, not terrible."

Well, this game sure came out to be a pleasant surprise. Like many, I had mostly written off the Need for Speed franchise as yet another victim of EA, ruined and wasted forever. But then this game came on a steep steep discount and I was able to get it for a basically symbolic amount. I gave it a try and suddenly, I have my new go-to racing game! Seriously, this one is shocking good! 

Covering the bases first, the game is super well made! The handling is really solid, intuitive and fun. To me, it felt completely natural and I was able to get used to it and do well pretty quickly. Drifting in particular is made very simple and reproducible for even casual players, while still having a ton of depth if you want to pursue mastery of it. Each car behaves differently and you can fine tune them to handle the way you want them to. The graphics are incredibly crisp and beautiful and don't show the tiniest bit of age. Love the tiny details like the cars shaking when you rev them. Performance is pretty good and I encountered no bugs whatsoever in all my playtime. To my absolute shock, there were no microtransactions or pay-to-win anywhere to be seen! Just a very standard, well designed progression system that allows you to unlock everything at a steady pace just by playing. Honestly, I have no idea how EA let this one slip! The Ubislop style side objectives are kind of a hassle though and don't really add much, but the good thing is you can just ignore them. The only major criticism I can offer here is that the soundtrack is utterly dreadful. Just unlistenable most of the time. I legit had to just turn the music volume off completely and I'd either just enjoy the sounds of the engines roaring or blast my own music selections. Including ones just lifted from older, superior NFS games.

Besides the handling, a racing game lives and dies by its roster of cars and this has to be one of the best in the franchise! There's quite literally a little bit of everything here - simple everyday sh!tboxes, executive luxury cars, exotic sports cars, ultra rare hypercars, badass JDM cars both old and new, offroad vehicles, classic retro vehicles, full on racecars and so so much more. And Ferraris too! Some of the coolest ones ever to boot, including the eyewatering LaFerrari! Seriously, this entire game is any car enthusiast's wet dream! And to make it a proper NFS game, we have a super in-depth and well made customization system that allows you to make these beautiful vehicles look exactly how you want them to, styling them all the way down to the sound of the exhaust. You also get a super deep performance tuning system that allows you to not only squeeze every last drop of performance out of these cars, but fine tune them for the specific behaviour you want them to have. Do you want a more loose and street savvy oldschool NFS style that can race and drift and drive cops mad? Sure! Do you want a more grounded GranTurismo style handling for true motorsport realism? Go for it! You want a pure drift machine that spends more time sideways than forward? You got it! You want an unstoppable off-road beast that can plow through any terrain like it's nothing? Absolutely! Combine this vast garage and versatility of performance with a solid map containing all kinds of tracks and options and fitted with races that allow every tier and class of car to shine and you have an absolute banger on your hands!

I wasn't sure how I'd feel about the day/night mechanic, but it's honestly brilliant! You get two similar, yet distinctly different experiences and it allows you to choose whether you want to level up to unlock new options and advance the campaign or if you want to earn cash to buy and upgrade cars. The tracks and style of races differ in both and bring new challenges that keep things exciting. The cop chases get pretty wild here and I would be lying if I said I didn't have at least a little fun there. However, I'm also happy that if you choose to race during the day, you just don't have to deal with cops! That's just wonderful.

Lastly, the campaign is...fine. A perfectly serviceable and simple story of street racers fighting against the law with a big bad crooked cop at the helm. It felt a lot more satirical and the cops are intentionally designed to act like exaggerated caricatures. It's something different for sure. Other than that, it's basically an above average Fast&Furious plot, but neither The C0ck or Din Benzin showed up, so that automatically makes it better. The campaign did its job of helping you get to know the city, the world as a whole and the major game mechanics and it didn't overstay its welcome. Can't complain really.

Overall, Need for Speed Heat really surprised me! This game overdelivers on every front and is genuinely one of the best made racing games we've gotten in recent years, especially in this kind of style. The excellent handling, the awesome graphics and the terrific selection of cars have solidified this as my new go-to racer for whenever I want to burn some rubber. It's a dream come true for any motorsports fan and it truly lets you indulge in all of your deepest desires. Asking for a good Need for Speed game these days is like asking for unicorn poop, so cherish this! It's not like the true classics of old, but damn does it ever come close! Just do yourself a favour, don't buy this at the ridiculous full price. Wait for a steep discount and get this cheap, then you'll be getting an absolutely sick deal!  Catch you on the road!

Longer version after first impressions:

Been playing NFS games since the very first ones in the 90s, loved the "HotPursuit"s, "Underground"s and the first "MostWanted" back in 2005 (which felt to me like the peak of the franchise). After that I had a long break (Carbon, although I heard it's good, didn't feel like something new back then and ProStreet totally put me off) until recently when I wanted to pick up the latest NFS games again per discount on Steam.
And I have to say that I enjoy HEAT thoroughly as it combines so much good fun stuff from previous games and is even better in a lot of ways:

- an open world city where you can switch between day and night mode. During the day you participate in legal races for cash without cops getting involved - they will chase you though when you provoke them in the city outside the races - whilst at night you race in illegal ones for reputation with a higher and increasing probability to get chased by cops. When you got the rig to max out the graphics, the city, the street reflections and skyline look absolutely stunning, esp. during sunsets, rainy weather and at night when you speed down from the hillsides towards it.

- a lot of car tuning and modding choices that remind me of the Underground and MostWanted games. And the way you direct your inner car parts choices towards 4 styles - on-road vs. off-road, racing vs. drifting - actually matters and influences your driving style (e.g. as long as you're on tarmac you accelerate way better but off-road you might suddenly become a sitting duck with the wrong suspension, tire and differential setup).

- driving/feeling/realism: You get to choose from 3 cars at the start and can buy new ones with the cash you earn from races. The driving feels very arcade-style-intuitive and simple as you initiate drifts whenever needed, both with and without the handbrake, with ease while it always remains a challenge to master extra-long ones for drift-spots and -competitions. As mentioned before, your tuning/parts choices actually impact the driving style so you do feel the little adjustments and improvements. The game also gives you the perfect amount of NFS non-realism: traffic remains loose (which is adrenaline-inducing enough when driving downhill with 250+ kph, trust me); in order for your car to get damaged there needs to be some at least major collision that stops you and driving through a gas station repairs that damage magically-instantly; and almost anything is destructible when you drive towards it (even full grown trees snap away like twigs) - but the best thing is you don't care because it just amplifies the action, esp. during cop chases when you're just happy you're getting away.

- track designs: not only are the track outlines very well designed - from curvy up- and downhill countrysides to tight Monaco-like inner city tracks - but once you progressed further to when you can also race on specific off-road tracks, you basically even get a little "Flatout"-mode in your NFS game on top, with varying rallye-ike terrain and sometimes crazy jumps, breaking all kinds of obstacles in your path to cut corners... it's just more insane fun stacked on top.

- cop chases: compared to previous MostWanted and HotPursuit titles, the cops are waaay harder to get rid of, keep up with you for longer and are more powerful, relentless and aggressive (they used to be merely annoying boxes on wheels that got instantly totalled by you like a bulldozer, which was also fun in its own way) plus they even have a pissy, personal attitude, exchanging plans and comments on comms, which makes you feel like you're not chased by some bots with the same comms and routines over and over but by equally capable, dirty-playing drivers - just on the other side of the law. And I absolutely love it; every cop chase is intense, personal and gets you to lock in. Not only because you don't want to lose your hard-earned cash from the day and - more devastatingly - almost all of your accumulated reputation from the night if you get busted, but also because the magically-repairing gas stations only do that for a limited amount of times each night - so getting into a chase actually feels like a big deal as its always tough on you and more consequential.

- music: the soundtrack is full of latin-infused bangers, ranging from chilled-out reggaeton and house to hiphop/rap and intense drum 'n bass which always seems to fit the current situation (cruising vs. racing, day vs. night, cinematic action soundtrack during cop chases). The soundtrack has always been one of the best parts of any NFS game and this one is no exception. No rock/metal tracks apparently but it all fits the beach city vibe.

- campaign/story/characters/dialogue: I've only played the first few missions so I can't say much about the main storyline yet, but imho the characters and acting/dialogue (so far, from the first impressions) are decent enough. I also like that you can choose a set character for yourself with their own voice, changeable appearance etc. and the story cutscenes happen with in-game models instead of live-action film actors. A few cliche and corny moments at times (e.g. when a cop behaves like some unhinged wannabe-psycho over a car he's impounding) but hey, it's a game and story about illegal street racing crews and at least it for sure hasn't inflicted that enormous cringe-feeling (again, so far) as the 2015 Need For Speed did - those live-action cut-scenes there instantly put me off and made me uninstall it.



So all in all, even as an NFS veteran, I can heavily recommend this title. If you ignore or embrace the sometimes cliched dialogue/acting, the campaign lends the game some variety and a good motivation for progression; there's tons to do with little open-world extras like beating speed-cams, drift- and time-challenges, jump stunts etc.; it looks stunning (the quality i.e. lighting, reflections and esp. at night actually reminded me a bit of Night City in Cyberpunk - just missing people and more traffic); the driving feels intuitively-simple but can still be challenging to master as it benefits from subtle and necessary adjustments; the great latin soundtrack is blasting on full volume constantly; the races (esp. the sprint races), after about 200+ kph, feel very fast and intense and the cop chases - esp. on "hard" difficulty - even moreso. Perfect recent NFS title that I'm happy to 100% at some point and made me fall in love with the franchise again.
